00017 
00018 Introduction
00019 ============
00020 
00021 **cnipol** is a software package designed to acquire and analyze data from the
00022 Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC) polarimeters at the Brookhaven National
00023 Lab (BNL). The first objective of this package is usually referred to as the
00024 "online" layer and designed to support the data acquisition and to provide
00025 a quick feedback by carrying a fast online analysis. The second objective is to
00026 execute a more rigorous offline data analysis and present the results in
00027 a systematic way. It is normally referred to as the "offline" part of
00028 **cnipol**.
00029 
00030 There is a wiki page with some details about the RHIC polarimetry:
00031 
00032 https://wiki.bnl.gov/rhicspin/Polarimetry
00033 
00034 The entry page with links to results obtained with cnipol can be found at
00035 
00036 http://www.phy.bnl.gov/cnipol/
00037 
00038 
00039 General remarks
00040 ---------------
00041 
00042 The code to analyse the data from the RHIC polarimeters has changed
00043 significantly starting 2010. Nevertheless, one may still find it useful to look
00044 through the older documentation which can be found at
00045 
00046 http://www4.rcf.bnl.gov/~cnipol/Analysis/pC/index.html
00047 
00048 
00049 How to configure and install cnipol
00050 ===================================
00051 
00052 The best way to start with the analysis is to clone the latest version of the
00053 code from the git repository. From the location where the package will be
00054 installed on your machine issue the following command:
00055 
00056     git clone https://github.com/rhicspin/cnipol.git
00057     cd cnipol
00058 
00059 If you plan to push changes back to the repository a github account is required.
00060 The source code in this case can be cloned via ssh protocol:
00061 
00062     git clone git@github.com:rhicspin/cnipol.git
00063     cd cnipol
00064 
00065 To make the processing of the data controllable and predictable we create stable
00066 releases of the code. The list of tagged stable releases can be viewed at
00067 https://github.com/rhicspin/cnipol/releases
00068 One may switch from the development version of the code checked out as above to
00069 the latest stable release by issuing the following command:
00070 
00071     git checkout stable
00072 
00073 The analysis framework depends on a few external libraries and programs including
00074 
00075 * ROOT
00076 * MySQL
00077 
00078 The data acquisition and online processing code depends on CERNLIB and CDEV.
00079 
00080 Before the code can be compiled and executed a number of environment variables
00081 must be set. We provide an example bash script `script/setup.sh` with predefined
00082 paths which should work on the eic cluster of the RACF (RHIC and ATLAS Computing
00083 Facility). Review and modify this script as needed to match your specific system
00084 configuration. This script can be ran with an optional argument for the RHIC run
00085 number, e.g. `run_id = 9|11|12|13`, execute in the terminal:
00086 
00087     source script/setup.sh [run_id]
00088 
00089 Once the environment variables are set the cnipol package can be build in
00090 `$CNIPOL_DIR` as:
00091 
00092     mkdir build
00093     cd build
00094     cmake .. -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=RelWithDebInfo
00095     make
00096 
00097 The compiled executables should appear in this `build` directory along
00098 with the cnipol libraries.
00099 
00100 
00101 How to run cnipol
00102 =================
00103 
00104 Make sure the following environment variables are set to valid locations before
00105 running the cnipol executables
00106 
00107     $CNIPOL_DATA_DIR
00108     $CNIPOL_RESULTS_DIR
00109 
00110 `asym` accepts a number of options which can be listed by running it with a `-h`
00111 option. Here we just give a few most common examples used to process regular and
00112 calibration data.
00113 
00114 To analyze a regular data file simply do:
00115 
00116     asym -r <meas_id>
00117 
00118 where `<meas_id>` is a unique name of a measurement, e.g. 12345.001. Note that
00119 usually `<file_name> = <meas_id>.data`. The program searches for the input
00120 <file_name> file in $CNIPOL_DATA_DIR and creates an output directory <meas_id>
00121 in $CNIPOL_RESULTS_DIR. Typically, the output directory contains a ROOT file
00122 with a predefined set of histograms, a log file (stdoe.log) with the entire
00123 output of the program, a PHP file with information about the measurement and
00124 results to display on the web, and a file with calibration results.
00125 
00126 To analyze a detector energy response to alpha-particles (a.k.a. alpha
00127 calibration) or a special test pulse measurement use the `--alpha` option:
00128 
00129     asym --alpha -r <meas_id>
00130 
00131 
00132 Batch processing multiple data files
00133 ------------------------------------
00134 
00135 Once in a while, when, for example, the **cnipol** code is modified one may need
00136 to re-analyze a large number of data files. This can be achieved in several ways
00137 by utilizing common linux tools. Here for completeness we provide a simple shell
00138 script that takes a text file containing a list of measurements (one `<meas_id>`
00139 per line) as a single argument and starts a certain number of parallel jobs in
00140 the background. The scripts for energy calibration and regular runs can be
00141 executed respectively as:
00142 
00143     script/run_asym_alpha.sh <meas_list>
00144     script/run_asym.sh <meas_list>
00145 
00146 
00147 How to produce summary plots
00148 ============================
00149 
00150 Often it is useful to see how polarization or other observables change from
00151 measurement to measurement during some period of time. To study such time
00152 dependence we developed `masym`, a program that runs on a set of measurements
00153 analyzed with `asym`. The output ROOT files produced by `asym` are used as input
00154 to `masym`. Executing the following command will create a `<meas_list>` directory
00155 in `$CNIPOL_RESULTS_DIR` with a ROOT file containing summary histograms:
00156 
00157     masym -m <meas_list>
00158 
00159 Here `<meas_list>` is a plain text file with a list of measurements to process.
00160 This file is assumed to exist in `$CNIPOL_RESULTS_DIR/runXX/lists/` and to have
00161 one `<meas_id>` per line.
00162 
00163 Optionally, the analyzer can provide a plain text file
00164 `$CNIPOL_RESULTS_DIR/runXX/hjet_pol` with H-Jet polarization values, and one file
00165 `$CNIPOL_RESULTS_DIR/runXX/cdev_info/cdev_NNNNN` per fill `NNNNN` containing
00166 intensity and other beam parameters from the CDEV services. Information from
00167 these text files will be used by `masym` in the summary plots. Information from
00168 CDEV can be extracted using the following script on any machine in the acnlin
00169 CAD cluster:
00170 
00171     $CNIPOL_DIR/script/get_fill_info.sh <NNNNN>
00172 
00173 where `<NNNNN>` must be replaced with an actual fill number.
00174 
00175 Similarly to `masym` we provide a program to study time dependences in a set of
00176 alpha-calibration measurements. This program is called `malpha` and can be
00177 invoked as:
00178 
00179     malpha -m <meas_list>
00180 
00181 where `<meas_list>` is a file in `$CNIPOL_RESULTS_DIR/runXX/lists/` with a list
00182 of unique names corresponding to measurements recorded by the polarimeters when
00183 no beam was present in the RHIC.
00184 
00185 
00186 Other polarimetry software packages
00187 ===================================
00188 
00189 Different people have been working on analysing polarimetry data. Some notable
00190 packages used for this purpose are:
00191 
00192 <table>
00193    <tr>
00194       <th>ags_cni</th>
00195       <td>
00196          <p>Code for AGS data analysis.</p>
00197          <p>AGS has a jet polarimeter much like the one at RHIC.
00198          Analysis code has branched a long time ago and is now supported by CAD.</p>
00199       </td>
00200    </tr>
00201    <tr>
00202       <th>hjet-analysis</th>
00203       <td>
00204          <p>Code for the H-jet polarimeter data analysis</p>
00205          <p>Supported by the RHIC Spin group. As many other analyses
00206          it's reader code is based on the code found in ```online/src/rdatautil.c```.</p>
00207       </td>
00208    </tr>
00209 </table>
